grammar_lessons.title: Present Simple Tense
grammar_lessons.subtitle: Learn the foundation of English grammar
content: The present simple tense is one of the most fundamental tenses in English. It is used to describe habits, unchanging situations, general truths, and fixed arrangements.
Understanding when and how to use the present simple is essential for effective communication in English.
grammar_lessons.formula: Subject + Base Verb (+ s/es for he/she/it)

uses.title: General Truths
uses.example: The sun rises in the east.

examples.explanation: This describes a regular job or routine.
Third person singular uses -s form of the verb.
This is a general truth or scientific fact.

tips: Remember to add -s or -es for third person singular (he, she, it)
Use present simple for facts and permanent situations
Time expressions like "always", "usually", "often" are common with present simple

grammar_lessons.title: Present Continuous Tense
grammar_lessons.subtitle: Actions happening now and around the present
content: The present continuous tense describes actions that are happening right now or around the present time. It emphasizes the ongoing nature of an action.
This tense is formed using a form of "be" (am, is, are) plus the verb with -ing ending.

uses.title: Actions Happening Now
uses.description: What you are doing at this moment

uses.title: Temporary Situations
uses.example: She is staying with friends this week.

examples.sentence: I am studying English right now.
They are building a new house.
examples.explanation: Action in progress, not necessarily right now.

examples.sentence: We are going to the cinema tonight.
examples.explanation: Future arrangement that is already planned.

tips: Always use am/is/are before the -ing verb
Use present continuous for temporary actions
Some verbs (like, know, understand) are rarely used in continuous form

grammar_lessons.title: Past Simple Tense
grammar_lessons.subtitle: Learn how to form and use the past simple tense
content: The past simple tense is used to describe completed actions in the past. It is one of the most common tenses in English.
Regular verbs form the past simple by adding -ed to the base form, while irregular verbs have unique past forms.

uses.title: Completed Actions
uses.description: Actions that finished in the past

uses.title: Past Habits
uses.description: Things you did regularly in the past

tips: Use past simple for actions that are completely finished
Time expressions like "yesterday", "last week" are common

grammar_lessons.title: Future Tenses
grammar_lessons.subtitle: Learn about will, going to, and present continuous for future
content: English has several ways to express the future. The most common are 'will', 'going to', and present continuous.
Each form has specific uses and contexts.

grammar_lessons.title: Present Perfect Tense
grammar_lessons.subtitle: Master the present perfect tense and its various uses
content: The present perfect connects the past with the present. It describes actions that happened at an unspecified time or have relevance to now.
It is formed with 'have/has' + past participle.

grammar_lessons.title: Conditionals
grammar_lessons.subtitle: Learn zero, first, second, and third conditionals
content: Conditionals are used to talk about hypothetical situations and their consequences.
There are four main types: zero, first, second, and third conditionals.

questions.question: Which sentence is correct?
options: I go to school every day.
I am going to school every day.
I goes to school every day.
I going to school every day.
questions.explanation: The present simple is used for habits and routines. "I go" is the correct form.

questions.question: Choose the correct form: She _____ coffee in the morning.
questions.explanation: Third person singular (she) requires the -s form: "drinks".

questions.question: Which sentence uses present simple correctly?
options: The sun is rising in the east.
The sun rises in the east.
The sun rose in the east.
The sun will rise in the east.
questions.explanation: General truths use present simple: "The sun rises in the east."

questions.question: What is the correct form? I _____ a book right now.
questions.explanation: Actions happening now use present continuous: "am reading".
